messageBody:
I find Hamcrest is a reasonable framework, so some of my custom
assertions I can write as Hamcrest classes. The dotmesh framework
sounds interesting.



I'd like to contribute a lot of JavaDocs for JUnit, because they have
been sorely lacking. Now that I have a better idea of what is available
with JUnit 4, I'm regretting not adopting it sooner.



My assertRecent() method looks like this:





/**

* Assert that a time stamp is within the specified range of time
compared

* to now. For example, calling the method with 100 milliseconds
will

* compare the date passed in to System.currentTimeMillis() - 100.
If the

* date is newer than that, the assertion passes. If the date is
older,

* the assertion fails.

*

* @param timeStamp the date to compare

* @param numMillis the range of milliseconds that is still
considered good

*/

public static void assertRecent(Date timeStamp, long numMillis) {

long compare = System.currentTimeMillis() - numMillis;

assertTrue(

String.format("The date [%d] is too old. Compared to
[%d].",

compare, timeStamp.getTime()),

compare < timeStamp.getTime());

}



It's not too difficult. If dotmesh is extensible, you could have
something like:



assertThat(timestamp).within(numMillis);



From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
David Saff
Sent: Friday, February 19, 2010 2:22 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Additional assertions/hamcrest verifiers





Berin,

I've been working on, but not publicizing, an alternative assertion
package for Java test frameworks called dotmesh, which automatically
creates assertions for every public boolean method on non-final
classes, which would allow:

On Thu, Feb 18, 2010 at 2:24 PM, Loritsch, Berin C.
<berin.loritsch@... <mailto:berin.loritsch%40gd-ais.com> > wrote:
> There are some assertions that I find myself re-implementing a lot,
> including regex matching, collection checking, etc. Of course, I'm
just
> recently upgrading to JUnit 4 so if I'm missing something, please
point
> me in the right direction. Below is my list and what they might map
to:
>
> assertDifferent(Object first, Object second) -> assertThat(first, not(
> equalTo( second ) ) );

assertThat(not(first)).equals(second);

> assertEmpty(Collection<?> collection) -> assertThat(
collection.size(),
> equalTo(0) );

assertThat(collection).isEmpty();

> Note: I would like a nice one that reads like this: assertThat(
> collection, isEmpty() );
>
> assertContains(T item, Collection<T> collection) -> assertThat(
> collection, hasItem( item ) );

assertThat(collection).contains(item);

> assertMinimum(int num, Collection<?> collection) -> assertThat(
> collection.size(), greaterThanOrEqualTo( num ) );

Don't have a good one for this.

> Note: It might be nice have one that reads like this: assertThat(
> collection, hasAtLeast( num ) );
>
> What I can't find an equivalent for is:
>
> assertRecent(Date timeStamp, long numMillis) -> Ensures a date is
within
> a certain number of milliseconds of now. Useful when testing dates
that
> are created by an object as a result of an action (like last modified
> dates).

Nothing magic from dotmesh for this one. However, with a sensible
date/time framework like Joda, this might be easier.

> assertMatches(String regex, String content) -> Ensure a string
conforms
> to the regex. Useful when testing string results that embed values
> including dates or system values. The format of the string is
> important, but the variable aspects are problematic to generate a
clean
> equalTo clause.

assertThat(content).matches(regex);

The main holdups for dotmesh are:

1) Finding time to document well
2) Figuring out the right thing to do with third-party final classes.

David Saff
